title: Revenge of the monkeybus - photo bonanza. Sort of..

posts.content:
monkey wrote:Had a visit from Mr P today and we nailed a couple of jobs. Although he'll be disappointed to hear that I had to remove the shifter as I couldn't fit the lever with the base in place as there wasn't much space.

All good though and always great to see Mark.




What lever Matt ??


what the gear stick !!!

really !!!


Dam


Just shout if ya need extra hands again Matt


Mark

markp wrote:
monkey wrote:Had a visit from Mr P today and we nailed a couple of jobs. Although he'll be disappointed to hear that I had to remove the shifter as I couldn't fit the lever with the base in place as there wasn't much space.

All good though and always great to see Mark.




What lever Matt ??


what the gear stick !!!

really !!!


Dam


Just shout if ya need extra hands again Matt


Mark

Yeah, what a bummer huh? It can't be fitted in situ. The shelf gets in the way.

Good news, Picked up the roof parts from the powdercoaters.
Bad news, Away this weekend and then for a week from Thursday.

Going nowhere fast.

Great News!
I have wheel tub mats down and i am fitting seat belts! LOL

KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK>>>>>looking Ace...

Bumpers, over-riders and towel rails now back from the paint shop as well. Also picked up the deluxe bumper trims when in vegas.
I'll hopefully get a chance to fit them at some point.

Right Matt

Let's have some dead lines from ya !!!!

when's he going to be on the road ...... always good to make ya focused when you have dead lines bro

You popping along to Stanford Hall next weekend for a boost of energy to get ya bus finished


Mark

markp wrote:Right Matt

Let's have some dead lines from ya !!!!

when's he going to be on the road ...... always good to make ya focused when you have dead lines bro

You popping along to Stanford Hall next weekend for a boost of energy to get ya bus finished


Mark

Hi Mark

I doubt it. Just a lot going on in my personal life at the moment. The bus is having to take a back seat at the moment.

Ok, so back into it.

Trimmed the rear panels tonight.

Those look good!
Pray tell the details...
Trimmed means you have covered with vinyl?

What did you do...PLEEEEEEEEZZZZZZZZZZZEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE

It's pretty easy. Buy vinyl. Buy blank cards. Draw around them, add a bit on for the edges. Cut out covers. Glue them.

Simples.

The vinyl,is the same that is used for my seats, door cards etc. I couldn't get it in the UK, so got Carol to send some to my hotel when I was in Vegas last month.

This mornings quick job.


A quick template made, a bit of scrim foam to pad it and then vinyl over the top. Will look fine when the panel is fitted on it.

Had a quick play at starting to fit the seat back wraps for 10 minutes this morning. All quite scary!! Pics to follow!

Update: Just did this in my lunch break:




Doesn't look too difficult a job huh? Well it's not persay, but it does require attention to detail.Except they were so oversized it took a lot of trimming to get them to fit. Then an equal amount of work to get the seams to run nicely along the edges. The top and side is the most important part to get right as its on display. The ends are tricky as well. They're not perfect, but good enough. I can always try to tidy them a little more once the seat base trim and rubber mat is fitted.

I've covered the whole back as I couldn't be arsed to cut the majority of it out, plus its going to be obscured by the camping interior anyway.

Edit: Did the other side to get them both done! It was much harder as the seam had a really pronounced join. Its not quite as straight as the other side, but its as good as I could get it.

Fitted the stainless steel separator trim and trimmed up the rubber base mats. It looks like it will be pretty tidy when it's completed. I resisted gluing it tonight, as I want to get it right and I think I'd just rush it tonight.

Pics tomorrow when it's done.
